=== Game Rules ===
Game rules in natural language:
Overview:
• Game Type: This is a grid‐based puzzle game in the spirit of Sokoban. You control an avatar (a knight) that moves around a level filled with immovable walls and floors, along with movable boxes and stationary holes.

Game Mechanics:
• Movement & Interaction: You guide the avatar, and when it bumps into walls it simply steps back—that is, walls block your progress. Boxes are passive objects that you can push around. If the avatar collides with a box, the box will “bounce” forward.
• Special Interactions: When a box runs into a wall and then bumps into another box (as described by “box wall box”), it triggers an “undo” of all recent moves. This likely prevents unwanted chain reactions or incorrect pushes.
• Scoring & Removal: The key interaction is with holes. When a box touches a hole, it is “killed” (removed from the level) and you gain a point. The game ends in a win when all boxes have been removed from the board.

Objective and Win/Loss Conditions:
• The objective is to remove all the boxes by pushing them into holes. The level is won when the count of boxes reaches zero.
• Losing might occur if you end up in a situation where you can no longer maneuver the boxes into the holes—although specific loss conditions aren’t laid out, poor moves (especially ones that trigger the undo action) might force you to restart.

Overall Strategy:
1. Plan Your Moves: Since your goal is to strategically push boxes into holes, take time to observe the starting layout—including the positions of the boxes, holes, and walls. Identify which boxes can be pushed straight into holes with minimal maneuvers.
2. Use Walls to Your Advantage: Walls restrict both your movements and those of boxes. They can help guide the box’s trajectory when bounced forward. However, be cautious—a misdirected push might cause a box to hit a wall and another box, triggering an undo of all moves.
3. Think Ahead: Avoid accidental collisions that force you to reverse your progress. Use careful, incremental moves, and always consider where the box will go when you push it.
4. Manage Risks: The “undoAll” trigger means that if a box collides with a wall and another box in the wrong way, you’ll lose your progress, so work to prevent situations where boxes become entangled. Try to clear one box at a time if possible.
5. Practice Precision: The “bounceForward” mechanism helps move boxes, but it requires precise alignment. Work on pushing boxes in ways that have them naturally fall into holes without causing chain reactions that force a reset.

In short, this game challenges you with spatial puzzles where each move can have a big impact on the board layout. By planning your moves carefully and using the environment to your advantage, you’ll gradually push all the boxes into the holes and win the level.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_LEFT
2: ACTION_RIGHT
3: ACTION_DOWN
4: ACTION_UP

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.
